questions.question_text: A department is reporting network issues. Users can ping each other and the switch, but not the default gateway. When looking at a wiring diagram and a physical blueprint, a technician notices the 1000BaseLX SFP connects to a distribution switch via a cable that runs behind a large industrial refrigerator. The technician also notices both switches have been worked on recently. Which of the following is MOST likely the issue?

comments.content: Yes, Answer is B. You can't short fiber, and it is immune to EMI. Also attenuation only occurs in very long distances, which doesn't seem to be the case here.
Also, the switches have been worked on recently. Someone could have plugged the patches incorrectly.

discussion.content: Fiber is immune to EMI so A is incorrect. C and D also pertain to copper cables, so the correct answer should be B.

This is a hideous insult to basic networking concepts. True fiber uses light and is immune to EMI for the most part. I'm seriously starting to doubt the authenticity of this website and its administrators for not fact checking a site that is suppose to prepare you for an official certificiation.

comments.content: Its not the site, its the way CompTIA format their questions, which is questionable. Most likely the answer is A, EMI, but its all on how CompTIA justify why.
This was a real question I got in the Network+ exam. The admins do fact check

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Option B, “TX/RX reverse”, refers to a situation where the transmit (TX) and receive (RX) fibers are reversed during recent work on the switches. This could prevent the proper operation of the network.

Selected Answer: A
B, C and D have no sense. A however does. Fiber is immune to EMI but the SPF module located close to the source of EMI is not immune. Inside the SPF module there are semiconductors and circuits which can be affected by EMI. To protect the SPF module from EMI, technicians can place an SPF cage which will play the role of a shield.

a cable runs behind a fridge there is no specification for what type of cable so it is EMI
1000sx sfp does not mean is fiber could be something else
Good Lord this is a horrible question...
While they do mention fiber, its not in reference to the cable that runs behind the refrigerator.

Selected Answer: B
Fiber is immune to EMI from the refrigerator. So the BEST answer is B TX/RX reverse.

Selected Answer: B
LX is immune to EMI... so B
Ridiculous answer here. B is correct
A? Fiber should be unaffected by EMI. Whattup?
I am going with B as well. Makes the most sense.
has anyone taken the Comptia Network + exam and this was one of the questions and they answered EMI and got it correct. this does not make any sense to me
I really hope I don’t get some of these questions. I mean really.

comments.content: It does, actually. It says it is using a 1000BaseLX SFP connector, which is a standard for Fiber Optic, it cannot be a copper cable.

discussion.content: Indeed, the question does not exactly specify what type of cable is run behind the industrial refrigerator. Therefore, the answer (A) is correct assuming that the cable conforms to a UTP specification.

The fibre connections to the switch use transceivers and it sounds like the switches arent far from the EMI interference so therein lies the problem. None of the other answers can apply since its a fibre cable.

CompTIA questions and answer aren't always going to make sense. The key is to eliminate all the they answers provided. The question says, "Which of the following is (MOST) likely the issue". By reading the question, we can eliminate attenuation and short off top. The question also states, "users can ping each other and the switch", meaning all cable connections are good. TX/RX reverse can't possibly be the issue, leaving answer A, EMI. I honest don't think its fair how they design their questions. We all are familiar with each answer and know exactly what they are but the way the questions are set up is deceitful and a lot times they can be vague.

comments.content:
I could be wrong but if the users are aconnected on the same broadcast domain (switch) they will be able to ping each other but they may still be unable to ping the default gateway due to reversed tx/Rx.

Users connect to the switch using copper cable and switch connects to the gateway device using fibre.
Honestly sounds like they want you to fail...

discussion.content: I feel that A is the best answer. The question does not state what type of cable is being run behind the large industrial fridge. "1000BaseLX SFP connects to a distribution switch via a cable that runs behind a large industrial refrigerator." It also states that the users can ping each other.

comments.content:
Only two types of cable can directly connect to a 1000BaseLX SFP; Single-Mode Fiber and Multi-Mode Fiber. Any other cable type would require a media converter (which isn't mentioned). The only other possibility is that the SFP is connected to a core switch, and a UTP cable is running to the distribution switch. But there's no mention of another switch.

So, as it stands, the only possible answer is B.
That would require a media converter which isn't mentioned.

discussion.content: I am assuming that the transceiver is going from UTP to fiber. that was my initial thought.

its true fiber is not affected by EMI.
All the answers are dumb. None of them make sense here
Open/short

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have been tasked with testing a CAT5e cable. A summary of the test results can be found on the screen.
//IMG//


Instructions -
Step 1: Select the tool that was used to create the cable test results.
Step 2: Interpret the test results and select the option that explains the results. After you are done with your analysis, click the 'Submit' button.
Step 3: You have determined that the original crimp is faulty. Re-crimp the cable connector using the T568B cabling standard. Choose the correct cable for each pin in the connector by clicking on the pin and selecting a cable color.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: OBJ-5.2: Cable certifiers can provide a “pass” or “fail” status following the industry standards and can also show detailed information such as “open,” “short,” or the length of the cable.

The answer to Step 1 is wrong. It is not Cable Certifier, it is a Toner Probe. A Toner Probe produces a report on any opens, shorts, or miswires like the cable test result in the graphic.
Cable certifiers are used to determine whether your network meets specific IOS or TIA standards, ie Cat 5e, Cat 6, Cat 7)

comments.content:
You are thinking of a cable qualification test. Cable certifiers are also called TDRs (which shows breaks in the wire). Now take note that if it shows open/short and the length is still the same means it's crimped wrong. 

Source: I am a field technician at an ISP company.
Also, Toner probes are used to check where the cable is connected to, not to detect how long a cable is or if there is a short. Stop misleading people.
lol really? bc my fluke toner makes a beeping noise and that's about it. It can check for continuity but it does not generate anything remotely similar to this PBQ diagram.

discussion.content:
you can rule out host based firewall as the ports are open (49) for local access and it works!
1) down
TACACS +Server Time 
I take it they are increasing the time the server will allow a login attempt to remain for processing? If so why did they not receive a time out error? I would debug the connection and see what is happening. It may well be that due to latency that more time is needed. But to assume that is wrong. Test and verify! So my 1st question is has this ever worked? If so when? what changed btw when it last worked and now? Where is the baseline for comparison? I've done networking for years and I must say these questions significantly lack crucial information! No wonder my network credentialed newbies come to me …. Look at what you are teaching them.... half truths and guess work.

comments.content: No. The time (system clock) on the TACACS+ server need to be updated. It is common for user to be unable to authenticate with a server if there is a mismatch between their system times. That's why the Network Time Protocol (NTP) is so important.

discussion.content:
Key phrase: "AAA server to manage network device access"
What fits that criteria? TACACS+
Keep it simple and move on.

"An unresponsive TACACS+ server can delay the processing of AAA requests. A Cisco Nexus 5000 Series
switch can periodically monitor an TACACS+ server to check whether it is responding (or alive) to save time
in processing AAA request"
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5000/sw/security/b_Cisco_Nexus_5000_Series_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide/Cisco_Nexus_5000_Series_NX-OS_Security_Configuration_Guide_chapter5.pdf
By process of elimination, B is the answer. Don't try to make sense of the question. Research each answer and understand they don't apply move on : )

comments.content: None of the other answers make sense. Time can be a factor when it comes to authentication so had to be B.

discussion.content: i got this one wrong any ideas why

questions.question_text: A large company uses an AAA server to manage network device access. The engineers can use their domain credentials to access all other servers. Currently, the network engineers cannot access the AAA server using domain credentials, but they can access it using a local account. Which of the following should the engineers update?

discussion.content: This answer makes complete sense as it increases the density of the switch. But remember it must be used at both ends of the cable to work.see http://www.cables-solutions.com/differences-between-sfp-bidi-sfp-and-compact-sfp.html
Single Strand - use bi-directional

BiDi SFP allows a bi-directional communication on a single fiber by using wavelength multiplexing (WDM), which makes CO and CPE connection more simple. Compact SFP enormously increases CO port density by combining two single fiber transceivers into one SFP form factor.
It's a Bi-Directional (BiDi) transceiver. Traffic in both directions on a single fiber using two different wavelengths. Reduce the number of fiber runs in half.
I'm not comprehending this question for some reason.
I dont understand this question at all

questions.question_text: A network technician has been asked to install an additional switch in an IDF, but all of the single-mode fiber is in use between the IDF and MDF. The technician has deployed new transceivers that allow for the use of a single fiber stand, providing the additional fiber needed for the new switch. Which of the following has the technician deployed?

A network administrator wants to ensure all traffic is inspected and abides by the AUP, and that malicious traffic is stopped. Which of the following features should be enabled on a firewall to meet this requirement?

discussion.content: Content filtering doesn't seem right. That seems more for employees visiting sites that are not business related.

comments.content: Please if you don't have a reasonable explanation and justification for another answer, don't give speculation and mislead people.

You are right when you said that content filtering is likely to be related to employees. This questions is looking for a feature that "abides by the AUP" (Acceptable Use Policy) which is pertaining to employees of a company. In addition, content filtering can stop malicious traffic.
